block.p: Your Sept. 10 front-page article on how the scientific experts who advise countries on changes in the climate now say human activity is causing global warming fails to address the basic question:
Your Sept. 10 front-page article on how the scientific experts who advise countries on changes in the climate now say human activity is causing global warming fails to address the basic question:
"Experts" notwithstanding, the atmosphere is not warming -- nor has it warmed in the past 16 years, ever since precise global data have become available for the first time from weather satellites.
So what produced this "important shift of scientific judgment" by the United Nations-sponsored Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change?

And what has caused its 1995 draft summary -- yet to be approved -- to conclude that what the drafters see as warming in the last few years "is unlikely to be entirely due to natural causes . . ." -- hardly a ringing confirmation of a human role?
There are no new, startling observations. What's changed is the theoretical projection of future warming, although it's not easy to learn this from the draft report.
The 1992 report by the intergovernmental panel had predicted an average global warming of 1.5 to 4.5 degrees centigrade (2.7 to 8.1 degrees fahrenheit) by the middle of the next century.

The panel's 1995 report drastically reduces these estimates, to 0.8 to 3.5 centigrade by the end of the 21st century, and states additionally that only 50 percent to 79 percent of this temperature increase will be realized by the year 2100. Is this the "feared greenhouse effect" that you refer to?

Now, if the panel would just reduce its estimates a little further, say to include a warming of zero degrees, then we could have perfect agreement between forecasts and observations. S. FRED SINGER President, Science & Environmental Policy Project Fairfax, Va., Sept. 13, 1995
